sentence.text: Patient 3 is the first child of nonconsanguineous parents; her mother is English, father Spanish.
She had a full head of shoulder length hair at birth and excessive hair growth over her body and limbs.
Her face is shown in Figure 1b.
Her early developmental milestones were delayed; she sat independently at 9 months, crawled at 13 months, and walked at 18 months.
At age 7 years she was referred for generalized hypertrichosis.
Although she was attending normal school she was experiencing some learning difficulties and behavior problems with frequent mood swings.
She had an unusual facial appearance (Fig. 5a), a muscular build, broad hands, and deep palmar creases.
Her echocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy with a central jet of aortic regurgitation.
She developed some communication difficulties that became more apparent in her teenage years.
Following psychiatric and neuro-psychological assessments it was concluded that she had manifestations of Asperger syndrome.
She also developed obsessive traits, has started to hoard objects and has motor and verbal tics that worsen when she is anxious.
At age 19 years her behavior had deteriorated and some of the changes were consistent with frontal lobe deficit.
An MRI showed normal appearances of the cerebral parenchyma and no evidence of significant cerebral atrophy.
However, there was mild enlargement of the pituitary fossa and moderate enlargement of the pituitary gland (10 mm by 11 mm) extending into the suprasellar cistern.
Her pituitary gland is being monitored by interval scanning and has remained stable with no evidence of any clinical or endocrine effects at the present time.
At her last cardiac review at age 19 years she had mild aortic valve regurgitation and mild septal hypertrophy that had not progressed.
